other_tests.findings: Microscopic examination of paraffin-embedded histopathological sections showed pancreatic tumor cells distributed in strips or diffuse sheets with characteristic salt and pepper-like nuclei. Immunohistochemistry confirmed CK and beta-catenin were positive, supporting the diagnosis of pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors.

The liver-associated tumor contained epithelioid cells, perivascular muscle-like cells, and adipocytes. Immunohistochemistry revealed GPC-3 was negative and Melan A was positive, supporting the diagnosis of perivascular epithelioid cell tumor (PEcoma).

The splenic tumor was a round-shaped nodule with clear boundaries, consisting of uniformly sized oval-shaped tissue-like cells and spindle-shaped muscle-like cells. Immunohistochemistry showed positive staining for both SMA and CD68, leading to the diagnosis of splenic hamartoma (myoid hamartoma).
Genetic mutation detection revealed heterozygous variants in BAP1 and TSC2 genes, suggesting a possible tumor susceptibility syndrome.
